name: 2,6-dimethoxybenzoyl chloride
Reason: 2,6-dimethoxybenzoyl chloride has a melting point that we can predict by considering its structural components. Starting with the basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C, we have substantial structural components to consider. The methoxy groups (two in total) can raise the melting point by approximately +5 °C due to additional molecular weight and the capacity for hydrogen bonding. The chlorine atom introduces a polar functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and rigidify the structure, estimated at around +10 °C. The benzene ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its planarity and rigidity, estimated at around +20 °C. The carbonyl group can also participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10 °C.
